RE: (1). “one key difference between seasonal and pandemic flu is how many people are susceptible” –I cannot believe that the general population right now is only “partially susceptible” - ALL are susceptible.
You make that point but it’s tricky to then talk about the 2009 swine flu season and talk only about “humidity” which is not the only suppressive factor during the summers. The far greater factor is direct sunlight. No known virus survives direct sunlight given enough exposure (less than the time from 10AM to 6 PM). In addition, people outdoors are more inclined to maintain distance between each other - a break in the road the virus must use to travel from person to person, especially given the frequency of breezes above 3 MPH when we are outdoors. You can be standing face to face at 2 feet talking to a person when there’s a 3-10 mph breeze and neither person will be exposed to the virus - it literally blows away.
RE: (2) “only a small percentage of people in the U.S. have been confirmed to have gotten COVID 19, the real total here is likely to be higher, maybe much higher. But even according to the biggest estimates, less than 5% of the population are likely to have been infected. So way more than 80% of the population is still susceptible. So, yes, it will be a while before we really know there’s reason to think COVID 19 could become a seasonal affliction just like the flu. But even if it is, that won’t likely give us the reprieve people are hoping for. …. there’s still too much of the population that’s still susceptible to the virus.”
With the above you are calling into question the numbers published by the CDC and spread by news corporations in America. Since March 16, the number of people known to have caught this illness is less than 0.5% of our total population. That means: success. 99.5% of the people have avoided this infection. Even 95% uninfected over time is still success. Yes, 99.5 % still susceptible but successful in avoiding infection, too. All that’s needed is for everyone to continue washing their hands (and using hand sanitizers) and maintaining a distance too great for the virus to travel. On that we agree.
RE: the world disrupting pandemic it is now.” — Of course we have not addressed an important fact about this “world disrupting” event. That is: the disruption is intentional on the part of politicians who hold top offices in government. They literally commanded the disruption, they just never bothered to mention that was the inevitable affect of their going too far in restricting people’s lives (like ordering them away from their jobs).

I'm biomedical researcher and from what I have read so far it might take quite long until we get rid of the virus. It's highly difficult to estimate how long the pandemic will last but an important factor is the mutation rate. For COVID-19, first studies show that SARS-CoV2 might have a lower mutation rate than SARS (which already has a comparatively low mutation rate). Since the virus has appeared in autumn, only a couple of mutations have been detected in samples across different countries (I once made a video about the evolution of SARS-CoV2). So instead of being vulnerable against the virus after a while again (like it is the case with influenza virus) this might be good news regarding immunity. But let's see!
